attachments.title: Germany's vaccine regulator reports 31 cases of blood disorder after AstraZeneca shot
attachments.text: Germany's vaccine regulator said on Tuesday it has recorded 31 cases of a rare blood clot in the brain, nine of which resulted in deaths, after people received a COVID-19 vaccine from AstraZeneca.

text:
Interestingly, this kind of blood clot is super rare, and because it is super rare we don’t actually have good confidence in how rare it is (large error bars).
30 in a million is higher than most estimates (2-6 per millions).
but those estimates have been trending up over time, because we have gotten better at detecting it.
(Same thing with increased number of people with autism etc for decades)
and no doubt we have never been trying as hard to detect it as now.
(this is from <https://www.sciencemediacentre.org/expert-reaction-to-news-that-germany-has-halted-vaccinations-with-the-oxford-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine/>)

text:
<@U01CQTKB86N> That's not clear yet. The vaccine commission wants to decide that until the end of April. Apparently there are ongoing studies if it would be possible to use a different vaccine and they want to evaluate the results of those before giving a recommendation. Currently using a different vaccine for the 2nd dose is not allowed, and as far as I understand it's also not allowed to "switch" and start over with a different vaccine, though the phrasing of the news reports is a bit vague on that.

I don't know what happens to people who should receive their 2nd dose before a decision has been made. I can't find clear info on that.
